facts.text: This appeal is directed against an appellate judgment of a Division Bench of the Madras High Court dated November 27, 1945

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjea, J. This appeal is directed against an appellate judgment of a Division Bench of the Madras High Court dated November 27, 1945, reversing the decision of the Subordinate Judge of Mayuram made in Original Suit No. 34 of 1943.

facts.text: The Division Bench reversed the decision of the Subordinate Judge of Mayuram made in Original Suit No. 34 of 1943

anchor.surface_text: reversing the decision of the Subordinate Judge of Mayuram made in Original Suit No. 34 of 1943. There is numberdispute about the material facts of the case which lie within a short companypass and the companytroversy centers round one point only which turns upon the companystruction of a wall left by one Kothandarama Ayyar to whom the properties in suit admittedly belonged.

facts.text: There is no dispute about the material facts of the case

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute about the material facts of the case which lie within a short companypass and the companytroversy centers round one point only which turns upon the companystruction of a wall left by one Kothandarama Ayyar to whom the properties in suit admittedly belonged. Kothandarama, who was a Hindu inhabitant of the District of Tanjore and owned companysiderable properties, died on 25th April 1905,

facts.text: Kothandarama Ayyar was a Hindu inhabitant of the District of Tanjore and owned considerable properties

anchor.surface_text: Kothandarama, who was a Hindu inhabitant of the District of Tanjore and owned companysiderable properties, died on 25th April 1905, leaving behind him as his near relations his adoptive mother Valu Ammal, his widow Parbati and two daughters Nagammal and Gnanambal, of whom Nagammal, who became a widow during the testators life time had an infant daughter named Alamelu.

facts.text: Kothandarama died on 25th April 1905

anchor.surface_text: died on 25th April 1905, leaving behind him as his near relations his adoptive mother Valu Ammal, his widow Parbati and two daughters Nagammal and Gnanambal, of whom Nagammal, who became a widow during the testators life time had an infant daughter named Alamelu. Kothandarama executed his last will on 13th March, 1905,

anchor.surface_text: leaving behind him as his near relations his adoptive mother Valu Ammal, his widow Parbati and two daughters Nagammal and Gnanambal, of whom Nagammal, who became a widow during the testators life time had an infant daughter named Alamelu.

facts.text: Nagammal became a widow during the testator's lifetime and had an infant daughter Alamelu

anchor.surface_text: of whom Nagammal, who became a widow during the testators life time had an infant daughter named Alamelu. Kothandarama executed his last will on 13th March, 1905, and by this will, the genuineness of which is number disputed in the present litigation,

facts.text: Kothandarama executed his last will on 13th March 1905

anchor.surface_text: Kothandarama executed his last will on 13th March, 1905, and by this will, the genuineness of which is number disputed in the present litigation, he gave an authority to his widow to adopt unto him a son of his second daughter Gnanambal,

facts.text: Genuineness of the will is not disputed

anchor.surface_text: and by this will, the genuineness of which is number disputed in the present litigation, he gave an authority to his widow to adopt unto him a son of his second daughter Gnanambal, should she beget one before January, 1908, or in the alternative any of the sons of his two nephews, if the widow so chose.

anchor.surface_text: he gave an authority to his widow to adopt unto him a son of his second daughter Gnanambal, should she beget one before January, 1908, or in the alternative any of the sons of his two nephews, if the widow so chose. The suit, out of which the appeal arises, was companymenced by Raju Ayyar, who was a son of the testators nephews and was taken in adoption by the widow in terms of the will

facts.text: Suit commenced by Raju Ayyar, son of testator's nephews, adopted by widow in terms of the will

anchor.surface_text: The suit, out of which the appeal arises, was companymenced by Raju Ayyar, who was a son of the testators nephews and was taken in adoption by the widow in terms of the will and it was for recovery of possession of certain properties, known as Kothangudi properties

facts.text: Suit for recovery of possession of Kothangudi properties

anchor.surface_text: and it was for recovery of possession of certain properties, known as Kothangudi properties which formed part of the testators estate on the allegation that under the will mentioned above, these properties were given to Nagammal, the widowed daughter of the testator for her life-time,

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged Kothangudi properties given to Nagammal for lifetime under will, no disposition of remainder, vested in plaintiff as adopted son on Nagammal's death on 3rd January 1943

anchor.surface_text: but as there was numberdisposition of the remaining interest after the death of the life tenant, the properties vested in the plaintiff as the adopted son and heir of the deceased on the death of Nagammal which took place on 3rd of January, 1943.

facts.text: Nagammal died on 3rd of January 1943

anchor.surface_text: on the death of Nagammal which took place on 3rd of January, 1943. Gnanambal, the second daughter of the testator, was the first and main defendant in the suit,

facts.text: Gnanambal was first defendant, claimed entitled to Kothangudi properties absolute after Nagammal subject to payment of Rs. 5000 to Alamelu

anchor.surface_text: Gnanambal, the second daughter of the testator, was the first and main defendant in the suit, and she resisted the plaintiffs claim primarily on the ground that there was numberintestacy as regards the suit properties after the termination of the life interest of Nagammal, and that under the terms of the will itself she was entitled to get these properties in absolute right after the death of Nagammal, subject to payment of a sum of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu, the daughter of Nagammal.

facts.text: Alamelu was second defendant, died when suit pending in trial court, her heirs impleaded as defendants 3 to 9

anchor.surface_text: Alamelu was made the second defendant in the suit and as she died when the suit was pending in the trial companyrt, her heirs were impleaded as defendants 3 to 9. The first companyrt accepted the companytention of the defendant No. 1 and dismissed the plaintiffs suit.

facts.text: First court (Subordinate Judge) accepted defendant No.1 contention and dismissed plaintiff's suit

anchor.surface_text: The first companyrt accepted the companytention of the defendant No. 1 and dismissed the plaintiffs suit. On appeal to the High Court, the judgment was reversed and the plaintiffs claim was allowed.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court judgment and allowed plaintiff's claim

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court, the judgment was reversed and the plaintiffs claim was allowed. The defendant No. 1 has number companye up appeal to this companyrt.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 appealed to this court (Supreme Court)

anchor.surface_text: The defendant No. 1 has number companye up appeal to this companyrt. To appreciate the companytentions that have been raised by the parties to this appeal, it would be companyvenient first of all to refer briefly to the relevant provision of the will

facts.text: Paragraph 5 of will: whole village of Kothangudi and house at Injigudi to Nagammal with life interest, after her to Gnanambal and her children on payment of Rs.5000 to Alamelu

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 5, which is material for our present purposes runs as follows - The whole village of Kothangudi and the house at Injigudi, both of Nannilam Taluk, my daughter Nagammal, shall enjoy with life interest and after her the said property shall pass to my daughter Gnanambal and her children on payment by the latter of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu, Nagammals daughter.

facts.text: Paragraph 13 of will: village of Kothangudi shall be enjoyed by Nagammal as stated in paragraph 5

anchor.surface_text: By paragraph 13 provides that the village of Kothangudi shall be enjoyed by Nagammal as stated in paragraph 5.

facts.text: Widow adopted a nephew's son (plaintiff Raju Ayyar)

anchor.surface_text: who was a son of the testators nephews and was taken in adoption by the widow in terms of the will

facts.text: High Court held paragraph 5 did not come into operation since widow adopted nephew's son, not Gnanambal's son

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a companystruction of the will has found in favour of the plaintiff primarily on the ground that in the companytingency which happened in the present case, viz., that the widow took in adoption a nephew son of the testator, paragraph 5 of the will did number companye into operation at all.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored Subordinate Judge's decision

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal is allowed, the judgment and decree of the of the High Court are set aside and those of the Subordinate Judge restored.

facts.text: Nagammal enjoyed the Injigudi house so long as she was alive

anchor.surface_text: If the whole of paragraph 5 remains operative the Injigudi house must also be deemed to have been given to Nagammal for her life and in fact the evidence is that she enjoyed it so long as she was alive.

The cardinal maxim to be observed by courts in construing a will is to endeavour to ascertain the intentions of the testator. This intentions has to be gathered primarily from the language of the document which is to be read as a whole without indulging in any conjecture or speculation as to what the testator would have done if he had been better informed or better advised.

concepts.interpretation: Court reads the entire will to ascertain testator's intention regarding applicability of paragraph 5 across contingencies without conjecture.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: 5, 6 and 7 would, in our opinion, still remain operative even if the person adopted was a nephews son of the testator. No changes is made in paragrap

concepts.unlisted_description: Ascertain testator's intention primarily from language of will read as a whole, no conjecture.

anchor.surface_text: In construing the language of the will as the Privy Council observed in Venkata Narasimha v. Parthasarthy 42 I.A. 51 at p. 70, the courts are entitled and bound to bear in mind other matters than merely the words used. They must consider the surrounding circumstances, the position of the testator, his family relationship,

concepts.unlisted_description: Courts consider surrounding circumstances, testator's position, family relations to interpret will.

anchor.surface_text: and many other things which are often summed up in the somewhat picturesque figure The court is entitled to put itself into the testators armchair But all this is solely as an aid to arriving at a right construction of the will,

concepts.unlisted_description: Court places itself in testator's position to understand language used.

anchor.surface_text: So soon as the construction is settled, the duty of the court is to carry out the intentions as expressed, and no other. The court is in no case justified in adding to testamentary dispositions In all cases it must loyally carry out the will as properly construed,

concepts.interpretation: Court refuses to invent bequest or add words, applies existing provisions of paragraph 5.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s son of the testator, the adopted son gets only the Kokkur properties and the reversionary interest in Nallathukudi village after the death of the te

concepts.unlisted_description: Court must not add to or alter testator's words, loyally execute as construed.

anchor.surface_text: A question is sometimes raised as to whether in construing a will the court should lean against intestacy. The desire to avoid intestacy was considered by the Privy Council in the case referred to above as a rule based on English necessity and English habits of thought which should not necessarily bind an Indian court.

concepts.interpretation: Not binding on Indian courts unless justified by context or ambiguity; not to override plain words; here fortifies conclusion against intestacy.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the learned Counsel for the respondents is that paragraph 5 was meant to be operative only if Gnanambals son was adopted by the widow. As that was nu

concepts.unlisted_description: Presumption against partial intestacy invocable only on ambiguity, not to distort plain meaning.

anchor.surface_text: As Lord Justice Romer observed in Re Edwards Jones v. Jones 1906 1 Ch. 570 at p. 574, it cannot be that merely with a view to avoiding intestacy you are to do otherwise than construe plain words according to their plain meaning.

concepts.unlisted_description: Words in will to be construed according to plain meaning, not distorted to avoid intestacy.

issues.text: Whether there is intestacy as regards the remaining interest in the Kothangudi properties after the termination of Nagammal's life interest under the will

anchor.surface_text: the suit, out of which the appeal arises, was commenced by Raju Ayyar, who was a son of the testators nephews and was taken in adoption by the widow in terms of the will and it was for recovery of possession of certain properties, known as Kothangudi properties which formed part of the testators estate on the allegation that under the will mentioned above, these properties were given to Nagammal, the widowed daughter of the testator for her life-time, but as there was numberdisposition of the remaining interest after the death of the life tenant, the properties vested in the plaintiff as the adopted son and heir of the deceased on the death of Nagammal which took place on 3rd of January, 1943.

issues.text: Whether under the terms of the will Gnanambal is entitled to the Kothangudi properties in absolute right after Nagammal's death subject to payment of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu

anchor.surface_text: Gnanambal, the second daughter of the testator, was the first and main defendant in the suit, and she resisted the plaintiffs claim primarily on the ground that there was numberintestacy as regards the suit properties after the termination of the life interest of Nagammal, and that under the terms of the will itself she was entitled to get these properties in absolute right after the death of Nagammal, subject to payment of a sum of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu, the daughter of Nagammal.

issues.text: Whether paragraph 5 of the will comes into operation and governs the Kothangudi properties in the contingency where the widow adopts a nephew's son

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a construction of the will has found in favour of the plaintiff primarily on the ground that in the companytingency which happened in the present case, viz., that the widow took in adoption a nephew son of the testator, paragraph 5 of the will did number companye into operation at all. The disposition as regards Kothangudi property is, therefore, to be found exclusively in paragraph 13 of the will

issues.text: Whether in construing the will the court should lean against intestacy

anchor.surface_text: A question is sometimes raised as to whether in construing a will the court should lean against intestacy. Parthasarthy 42 I.A. 51 at p. 70, the courts are entitled and bound to bear in mind other matters than merely the words used. arguments.claim: Once construction settled, carry out expressed intentions only; no addition to dispositions

anchor.surface_text: So soon as the construction is settled, the duty of the court is to carry out the intentions as expressed, and no other. The court is in no case justified in adding to testamentary dispositions In all cases it must loyally carry out the will as properly construed

arguments.claim: No strong presumption against intestacy in India; only on ambiguity, not distort plain meaning

anchor.surface_text: A question is sometimes raised as to whether in construing a will the court should lean against intestacy. The desire to avoid intestacy was considered by the Privy Council... as a rule based on English necessity... which should not necessarily bind an Indian court... cannot be that merely with a view to avoiding intestacy you are to do otherwise than construe plain words according to their plain meaning.

arguments.claim: Paragraphs 4-8 not exclusive to Gnanambal son adoption; para 5 applies to all contingencies

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court... that paragraph 5 was meant to be operative only if Gnanambals son was adopted... We do not think that this is the correct way of reading the document. The testator undoubtedly contemplated different contingencies but a reading of the whole will does not show that he wanted to make separate and self-contained provisions...

arguments.claim: Provisions for daughters, wife, mother in paras 5,6,7 operative under all contingencies; not cancelled by later paras

anchor.surface_text: It was not the intention of the testator that on the happening of the second contingency, all the earlier provisions of the will would stand cancelled... the provisions made for the two daughters, the widow and the adoptive mother as made in paragraphs 5, 6 and 7 of the will... were meant to be applicable under all the three contingencies

arguments.claim: Testator made complete disposition of all properties with care for contingencies; unlikely to omit remainder

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the meticulous care with which the testator seems to have attempted to provide for the different contingencies that might arise and the anxiety displayed by him in making an effective disposition of all the properties he owned, it is not probable that he would omit to make any provision regarding the future devolution of the Kothangudi village

arguments.claim: Para 13 affirms para 5 for Nagammal; no alteration to para 5; superfluous repetition not excluding rest

anchor.surface_text: No change is made in paragraphs 11 to 16 with regard to the provision in paragraph 5 of the will. In paragraph 13 it is only stated that the village Kothangudi shall be enjoyed by Nagammal as stated in paragraph 5... The affirmation of a portion of the provision which is perfectly superfluous cannot exclude the rest.

holdings.text: the provisions made for the two daughters, the widow and the adoptive mother as made in paragraphs 5, 6 and 7 of the will and also the provisions for charities and payment of debts contained in paragraphs 9 and 10 were meant to be applicable under all the three contingencies referred to above.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions made for the two daughters, the widow and the adoptive mother as made in paragraphs 5, 6 and 7 of the will and also the provisions for charities and payment of debts contained in paragraphs 9 and 10 were meant to be applicable under all the three contingencies

holdings.reasoning_summary: Whole will read harmoniously shows no mutually exclusive provisions per contingency; earlier paras not cancelled by modifications in later paras for alternative adoptions.

holdings.text: the provisions of paragraphs 5, 6 and 7 would, in our opinion, still remain operative even if the person adopted was a nephews son of the testator.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of paragraphs 5, 6 and 7 would, in our opinion, still remain operative even if the person adopted was a nephews son of the testator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of existing para 5 provisions via interpretation, no invention required.
